WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Make sure you know your radicals!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: What if the rain actually tried to aim (ã‚ã‚) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, ã‚ã‚ and "aim" don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use "aim" to get to ã‚ã‚, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.

(é›², äº‘, yun=yÃ¼n, cloud) means rain , vapor or steam on the above, and something whirling beneath it . It describes the cloud whirling in the sky. These characters combined to mean â€œa cloud which carries rainâ€. humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The shape of the oracle bones is changeable. One painting is used to represent the sky, and three or two raindrops under it represent rain. The raindrops on the top may be connected to the horizontal painting, and there may be no painting pens on it. The rain-shaped characters of the Western Zhou Dynasty are connected in a straight line, similar to the small seal. Warring States text raindrops or writing water shape, see [å¦¾å­]ğ§Š’ pot. "Said Wen": "Rain, water comes from the clouds. It is like the sky, the sky is like the clouds, and the water is free. All rain belongs to the rain. ğ •², ancient Chinese."

The oracle bone inscriptions use its original meaning to refer to rain, "He Ji" 8329: "Toward the river, ã¢ (you) rain." "He Ji" 20397: "Renxu ã¢ (you) rain." Also used as a verb, it means rain, " Collection "9757: "Today's rain." "Collection" 12598: "Today's heavy rain."

Bronze inscription is used as a personâ€™s name, Ziyujue : "Ziyu." The word is also pronounced as " ğ©¹ ", which is used as a sacrificial name, [å¦¾å­]ğ§Š’ pot: "Rain (ğ©¹) Temple King." "Said Wen": " ğ©¹, the summer festival is happy to pray for the red Emperor to pray for sweet rain." "Book of Rites. "Yue Ling": "I ordered a secretary to pray for the people to pray for the mountains and rivers. The great emperor, to use Shengle. I ordered the hundred counties to worship the Baipi Qingshi to benefit the people, to pray for the grain." Zhang Zhenghong thinks this sentence is likely to refer to Incorporate King Sun Yat-sen into the hundred pirates, and carry out the sacrifice. Zhu Dexi and Qiu Xigui thought that the word " Yong " should be read.

The word " rain " in the Warring States Period is mostly used as the original meaning, "Shangbo Bamboo Book I." "Jian Yi" Jane 6: "Summer and rain, less (small) people's (but) daily grievances", which means that the summer is hot and rainy, and the people will resent God. "Shangbo Bamboo Book II. "Lupin Drought" Jane 4: "Women (such as) the sky does not rain, the stone will be burnt, the wood will die, not (its) want to rain or better than me, or must temple (wait) my name (ç¦œ)?" The whole sentence means that if it does not rain in the sky, the rocks will be scorched and the trees will die. The mountains and trees need rain more than we do. Why wait for us to perform the sacrifice?
humanum_short_description_en: Synopsis: The upper part of the oracle bones resembles the sky or clouds, and the lower part resembles raindrops. The form of the golden characters has changed, closer to the writing of seal script, but it still looks like rain. The original meaning is rain.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ] [yÇ”]
["Guangyun" Wang Juqie, Shangyu, Yun. ]
(1) Water falling from the clouds to the ground. When the volume of the small water droplets in the cloud increases to the point that they cannot be suspended in the air, they fall into rain.
(2) The metaphor of teaching, the teaching of teaching.
(3) Tandoori Fu's "Autumn Narration": "Always the chariots, the old, the rain comes; today, the rain does not come." It is said that the guests in the past also came when the rain, but now they do not come. Later, he used "rain" as a metaphor for his friends.
(4) The legendary one-legged bird.

Meaning Mnemonic
The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.

Reading Mnemonic
What if the rain actually tried to aim (ã‚ã‚) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.
Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, ã‚ã‚ and "aim" don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use "aim" to get to ã‚ã‚, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.
